title: Charging - positive rods and 2 conducting spheres

content.question: Two identical, electrically neutral conducting spheres, Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, are on insulating stands. Each sphere is connected to ground through a wire held in contact with the sphere by a student, as shown in the figure. A positively charged insulating rod is then brought close to each sphere. With the rods close to the spheres, the wire in contact with Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is removed while the other wire remains in contact with Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The rods are moved far away from the spheres, after which the wire in contact with Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is removed as well. Which of the following correctly describes the final net charge, if any, on the two spheres?

choices.label: Both spheres have a negative net charge.

Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has a negative net charge and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is electrically neutral.

Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is electrically neutral and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has a negative net charge.

content.answer: Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has a negative net charge and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is electrically neutral.
